inventory.commentary: Revised PENN file Merged groups 1 and 3, merged groups 2 and 4, added two additional senses Added features, modified examples, added commentary. ahouston 26sep06 added dummy sense 3, dummy sense 4. ahouston

sense.name: the rate or tempo of an activity
sense.commentary: tempo or relative rate of change PACE[+quantity][+rate][+tempo]
sense.examples: As the pace of the music increased, Sally ran faster. Mary thinks modern life is lived at too fast a pace. He rode the horse around the ring at an easy, relaxed pace. (rate of walking) The speaker picked up the pace of his talk when he realized he had only five minutes remaining. The costs have risen because supplies have not kept pace with demand. They worked at a great pace to finish the project. The pace of developments has accelerated in recent days.

sense.name: a unit of distance, approximately equal to a human stride
sense.commentary: footstep, step, stride - the length of a step, distance covered by a step PACE[+quantity][+length][+stride][+foot/+centimeter]
sense.examples: He stepped off ten paces from the old tree and began to dig. She stepped back a pace to let them through the line. The child made three paces to each pace of her father.

sense.name: an exercise of skill and training
sense.commentary: Idiom: put_through_one's_paces Note: always in the plural PACE[+activity][+exercise][+skill]
sense.examples: The trainer put the tiger through his paces in the ring. That math camp really puts the students through their paces.

sense.name: first place in a competition
sense.commentary: PACE[+relation][+position][+first][+competition] Note: a narrow extension of Sense 1, implies a best rate or tempo in a competition
sense.examples: At the swim meet, Bob was four strokes off the pace. A relatively unknown runner has set the pace during the first hour of the marathon.
